texts.text: Dek: And the winners may be...
Date-published: TKweekday, August TKday, 2016 9:01 AM EDT
We calculate the probable outcome for each individual Senate race, and then we use those probabilities to determine the likely seat counts on election night.
We estimate the probability of a win for each individual Senate race using publicly available polls in the
database. We average the polls using Pollster’s
that runs 100,000 simulations of the data to find the most likely polling average. (We show a random sample of 5,000 simulations). The model uses
ratings as “priors” -- starting points based on how accurately the Cook rating has predicted the outcome of Senate contests in the past.
When there are fewer than five available polls in 2016 or fewer than two polls since July 2016, we use the Cook ratings as our probabilities.

We run the simulations of the polling data out to Election Day, November 8. Obviously we don’t have polling data for the future, so the model assumes that the race generally continues along its current trajectory. The lack of new data means that the outcomes of the races get less certain as time goes on, so the probability of a leading candidate winning drops slightly over the gap between today and the election.

The model also estimates what proportion of voters are undecided in the polls as of today. We calculate the ratio of undecided voters to the margin of the difference between the top two candidates. This is because the smaller the margin between candidates, the more the undecideds will matter. We subtract that ratio of undecideds relative to the margin between the candidates from the overall probability of a candidate winning. The result is the our estimate of the final probability of a candidate winning on Election Day.

Finally, we simulated a Nov. 8 election 100 million times using the by-state probabilities. The number of times Democrats ended up with at least 51 seats is the probability of the Democrats gaining control of the Senate. The probability of a tie is the proportion of times the seat count landed at 50-50.
